fields.description:
Hello Atlassian,

Today I was helping a contractor attempt to clone one of our git repositories, who could not. We wasted an hour trying various solutions to the issue, until we realized that git support was not enabled by default in Sourcetree. Considering that the primary use of Sourcetree is to work with git, this is a baffling default. Please consider always enabling git support upon installation.

Thank you,

Aaron
fields.summary: Git Support Disabled by default

When I clone a repository from the _Remote repository_ screen, the cloned repository settings doesn't have any optional extended configuration configured in the resulting _Remote details_ under the repository settings.

My host root URL and username are both values configured in hosting accounts as used by the _Remote repository_ screen; as such I expect when cloning a repository from one of those accounts that the repository would have this information configured automatically instead of requiring me to do it manually.

(Also note that the _Stash_ option under _Host Type_ in the _Remote details_ dialog should probably now be _Bitbucket Server_ now to align with the _Hosting Service_ options for hosting accounts.)

fields.description:
The current version (SourceTreeSetup-2.3.1.0.exe) has become effectively unusable with the Git on my system, which I consider to be major severity.  After uninstalling and freshly reinstalling 2.3.1.0, I get errors of the following kind (and more) when try to open a Git repository directory.

*{{ERROR [date time] [number] [SourceTree.Diagnostics.FailureHandler] [HandleGeneralTaskFailure] - 'git status' failed with code -1: System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception: The system cannot find the file specified}}*
 *{{(C:\repositoryDirPath)}}*

Past versions of SourceTree worked fine with the same Git repositories.  As I explain below in the first comment to this issue, I believe the problem may be that SourceTree no longer sees and/or does not correctly use Git on my system.  This is despite the fact that I haven't changed the way that I install Git on my system.

A principle version of Git on Windows is "*Git for Windows*".   Obviously SourceTree must work with that version of Git.
 [https://git-for-windows.github.io/]

Instead of installing this version directly and minimally, one may instead install the "*Git for Windows SDK*", which also provides the integrated (MSYS2+MinGW) Linux environment that builds that very same version of Git.
 [https://github.com/git-for-windows/build-extra/releases/latest]

If Windows SourceTree is able to work with Git for Windows, it ought to also be able to work with that very same version of Git when it has been created in and by its development SDK environment.  It's the same executable application.

I've been using the Git for Windows SDK for a long time now.  Until now, past versions of SourceTree were able to work fine using the version of Git in the SDK's directory tree.

However, currently SourceTree (SourceTreeSetup-2.3.1.0.exe) does not correctly locate and use Git if it is present as part of the Git for Windows SDK.
 * On installation it sometimes confesses it cannot find Git on the system and asks for help locating it (cf. the git.exe list below for why this is not a simple question).
 * I've also had it fail to ask and merely assume it should be using "LibGit2Sharp", which is a .NET interface to libgit2.
 * When trying to open a git repository (something that worked in past versions of SourceTree), it currently fails with errors such as the one I quoted above.
 * See also the first comment about another user's experience with this same exception.

 

The ideal fix is to correct its ability to locate Git on a Windows system so that it does find and correctly use it when it is located within the SDK's directory tree.

In the meantime, a possible work around would be to supply directions on how to manually guide SourceTree so that it finds and uses the appropriate copy of git.exe within the Git for Windows SDK.  Since the SDK installs an integrated MSYS2+MinGW environment, there are actually up to six different choices for a relevant git.exe selection.  Some of these are relevant to use by the MSYS2+MinGW simulated Linux environment and therefore not appropriate for SourceTree's selection.

C:\git-sdk-64\cmd\git.exe
 C:\git-sdk-64\mingw64\bin\git.exe
 C:\git-sdk-64\mingw64\libexec\git-core\git.exe
 C:\git-sdk-64\usr\bin\git.exe
 C:\git-sdk-64\usr\lib\git-core\git.exe
 C:\git-sdk-64\usr\src\git\git.exe

Here are some differences and similarities between these applications:

C:\git-sdk-64\cmd\git.exe is by far the smallest.

C:\git-sdk-64\usr\src\git\git.exe is by far the largest.

C:\git-sdk-64\mingw64\bin\git.exe
 and
 C:\git-sdk-64\mingw64\libexec\git-core\git.exe
 are binary identical to each other (but may differ as choices in terms of context).

C:\git-sdk-64\usr\bin\git.exe
 and
 C:\git-sdk-64\usr\lib\git-core\git.exe
 are binary identical to each other (but may differ as choices in terms of context).

Hopefully it is possible to orient SourceTree to the most appropriate setting for the git.exe that it needs to use.

p.s. The original summary for this issue was this:
h3. "Windows SourceTree should work correctly with the Git for Windows SDK"
fields.summary: Opening repositories fails with System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception: The system cannot find the file specified

fields.description:
When performing a pull, if a file being updated by git is currently locked on the computer, SourceTree gives an error:
{quote}error: unable to unlink old '$file': Invalid argument

fatal: Could not reset index file to revision '$SHA'.
{quote}
SourceTree will then leave the repository in a mixed state. Files that had been fetched from a remote before encountering the locked file will appear as modified and unstaged.  This prevents just closing whatever program had a lock on the file and pulling again because the files are marked as unable to be overwritten, must stash or commit the changes.  The user must go through the process of identifying which unstaged files were affected by this mixed state, revert the files, and then will be able to pull successfully.

If this action was performed by a command line 'git pull', git will give an option to retry unlinking the affected file, or abort. Retrying allows the user to find and remove the lock on the file before continuing, and aborting reverts the repository to the state before initiating a pull.  Both of these states are much better than how SourceTree currently handles the situation.

Please add the ability to retry from this state, or abort the pull operation completely and display the error. 

I previously attempted to create a Discussion about this issue but received no response.  It is titled: "Unable to unlink old file issue, puts repository in inconsistent state"
fields.summary: SourceTree does not provide option to retry unlinking file in use

When a conflict occurs you have the an option to resolve it using my version or theirs. Regardless which you click it will show the following text:

[https://i.imgur.com/TAW9yre.png]

For those that do not wish to click the link read below:

"Please confirm you want to resolve these files using *their* state as at this commit: 'id'"

It will always say "their" regardless if you click on _'Resolve using mine'_ which can be confusing.

Bertrand

Invalid URI: The host name could not be parsed.

This issue is bit critical for us because our whole organisation is not able to use Bitbucket server due to this issue.

They seem to be in the order of:

Please change this to either alphabetical order or recently committed to order, not some confusing order in between.

fields.description:
Whenever you close and open source tree, the tabs are not in the order you left them when you last closed the program.

This is annoying because I quite-often have to restart SourceTree due to new freezing issues and the tabs are in the order I left them in version 1.x.
fields.summary: Repository tabs do not retain their order upon reload

fields.description:
It appears to be random but sometimes when clicking on a single file in the staging area, multiple files will be shown in the diff.

Normally this is just annoying and not a huge issue as the diff hunks show the file name at the top and one could discern the difference between the files.

What *IS* a huge concern is that the staging area shows one file selected, but has actually secretly selected multiple files so that when you do something like *right-click > discard* you are actually *discarding MULTIPLE FILES* when you think you're discarding one file's changes.

*This led me to be extremely confused on why I lost my work.*

The attached screenshot has information redacted, but shows *one* file selected, but the confirmation dialog is asking if I want to discard *two* files.

 

...please, Please PLEASE *PLEASE* do proper testing before releasing new versions. I have 11 (now 12) bug reports open for issues that have been INTRODUCED within the last few months... consider hiring people to test your software as it seems like there's no-one doing this except your users.
fields.summary: When clicking on a single file in the staging area sometimes multiple files are selected / shown

fields.summary: Fetch a branch with "folder" creates a invalid local branch without "folder"

fields.description:
on Win10, the beta

 

 

This one I've nailed down somewhat, after seeing it several occasions before
 * have a goodly list of prepared Local Repositories on the list – not sure if it happens when you actually add one
 * repeat using the +tab to use one, use it, close the tab, repeat on another repo etc.
 * after 3-7 tries, you won't be able to use the selected rep – double-cllicking it has no effect; event apparently lost
 * it actually seems to have something to do with the number of repos on the list. I just tried it again, and it's repos late in the list (maybe 20) which don't respond.
 * but if you restart ST, then you can be successful with even the last on the list..
 * I would add that double-clicking is obscure, if works once you understand it, and there don't seem to be any visible or other alternative methods to get a repo tab up.

fields.description:
From time to time SourceTree asks for Bitbucket password

!image-2017-09-14-21-48-06-233.png!

 

I enter correct password and everything works fine. But after some time the dialog appears again.

My Tools > Options > Authentication looks like this

!image-2017-09-14-21-51-02-650.png!

If I click on Edit I see the dialog that says Login Failed.

!image-2017-09-14-21-52-11-860.png!

 

I click Refresh OAuth Token button and the token gets refreshed successfully. But after some time, when Source Tree starts asking for password, I get back to this dialog and it again says that Login failed and I need to refresh the token again. This can happen every 10 minutes or once in 1-2 hrs. Very random.

 

The problem happens only on one of my computers. I'm using desktop, virtual and laptop. And the problem happens only on my desktop.

 

I've tried to uninstall and install SourceTree. Nothing helps. Please help with this annoying problem.
fields.summary: SourceTree keeps asking Bitbucket password

fields.description:
See community question [How do you get SourceTree to show Bitbucket team repos on New Tab > Remote?|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/How-do-you-get-SourceTree-to-show-Bitbucket-team-repos-on-New/qaq-p/631401] for more details.

When you try to clone a Bitbucket remote repo in New Tab > Remote, only repos from teams where you have "create repo" rights will be listed.  Repos to which you have full access, but from a team where you do not have "create repo" rights, will not be listed.

You shouldn't need "create repo" rights to see/clone an existing repo.  This is a pretty significant usability issue in environments with tighter access controls.  And it's not consistent with how Bitbucket itself behaves.  In Bitbucket you'll see all repos to which you have access, regardless of "create repo" rights.
fields.summary: Bitbucket team repos are not listed on New Tab > Remote

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
 # Create private Mercurial repository (for example use Bitbucket.org)
 # Checkout repository to some folder
 # Install Mercurial 3.8.4
 # Add local repository to SourceTree
 # Try to pull changes from SourceTree UI

*Actual result:* After some waiting error message "abort: authorization failed" is shown;
 !SourceTree-hg-3.8.4-authorization-error.png|thumbnail!
 *Expected result:* Changes are pulled without errors;
 *Also expected result:* Error messages should notice that Mercurial version 3.8.4 and older are not supported.

This situation happened when I updated SourceTree and not updated Mercurial for a long time. Even when I use embedded Mercurial. Workaround is to update mercurial (Embedded or System) but error message doesn't explain that.
fields.summary: Authorization (mercurial-credential-manager.exe) doesn't work with Mercurial 3.8

fields.description:
once when I was using Sourcetree v2.1.11, every time I start there is comfirn dialog pop up said some dictionary file is invalid and should delete or not, and I chose not for then.

today I update my Sourcetree to version 2.3.1 and the app just can not start up.

somehow I found a solution: uninstall the version 2.3.1 and reinstall v2.1.11 and start it up, the dictionary file thing dialog shows up again and I chose YES to delete that file and then install the version 2.3.1 and it starts up normally.

I'm sorry for not providing the exact content of the confirm dialog since it won't show up any more, I just remember it's a .dic file related to office/16.0/ blablabla.

And SORRY for my poor English.

 

Sourcetree is a great app, thank you team.
fields.summary: Dictionary file blocks Sourcetree 2.3.1 from starting up
